PHONE SCREEN DISPLAY SIGN 'YOUR PARTY HAS NOT CONNECTED VISION' A FEW SECONDS LATER, THE SCREEN CHANGES TO AN IMAGE OF THE CHILD FLOYD

direction.raw_text: b19 - b22 DELETED 12/7/65 B17 FLOYD IN VISION PHONE LITTLE GIRL OF FIVE ANSWERS CHILD Hello. VISION PHONE SCREEN DISPLAY SIGN 'YOUR PARTY HAS NOT CONNECTED VISION' A FEW SECONDS LATER, THE SCREEN CHANGES TO AN IMAGE OF THE CHILD FLOYD Hello, darling, how are you?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello Daddy. Where are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm at Space Station Five, darling. How are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm fine, Daddy. When are you coming home? 12/6/65                                                                                  b23 B17 CONTINUED FLOYD Well, I hope in a few days, sweetheart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm having a party tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I know that sweetheart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you coming to my party?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm sorry, darling, I told you I won't be home for a few days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When are you coming home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In three days, darling, I hope. FLOYD HOLDS UP THREE FINGERS. 12/6/65                                                                                  b24 B17 FLOYD One, two, three. Can I speak to Mommy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mommy's out to the hair- dresser.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is Mrs. Brown?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's in the bathroom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, sweetheart. Well, I have to go now. Tell Mommy that I called.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many days until you come home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three, darling. One... two ... three. Be sure to tell Mommy I called. 12/6/65                                                                                  b24a B17 CONTINUED CHILD I will, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, sweetheart. Have a lovely Birthday Party tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll wish you a happy Birthday now and I'll see you soon. All right, Darling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Bye, 'bye, now, sweetheart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning. I'd like the Vision shopper for the Pet Shop, please.

dialogue.raw_text: Just one moment. 12/7/65                                                                                  b25 B19 THE PICTURE FLIPS AND WE SEE A WOMAN STANDING IN FORN OF A SPECIALLY- DESIGNED DISPLAY SCREEN VISION SALES GIRL Good morning, sir, may I help you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I'd like to buy a bush baby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: APPEARS ON THE SCREEN OF A CAGE CONTAINING ABOUT SIX BUSH BABIES, BEAUTIFULLY DISPLAYED AGAINST A WHITE BACK- GROUND VISION SALES GIRL

dialogue.raw_text: Just a moment, sir. THE GIRL KEYS SOME INPUTS AND A MOVING PICTURE APPEARS ON THE SCREEN OF A CAGE CONTAINING ABOUT SIX BUSH BABIES, BEAUTIFULLY DISPLAYED AGAINST A WHITE BACK- GROUND VISION SALES GIRL Here you are, sir. Here is a lovely assortment of African bush babies. They are twenty Dollars each. 12/7/65                                                                                  b26 B19 CONTINUED FLOYD Yes, well... Pick out a nice one for me, a friendly one, and I'd like it delivered tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: TIME DURING THIS CONVERSATION, FLOYD SEE ELENA, SMYSLOV AND THE OTHER TWO RUSSIANS PASS HIS VISION PHONE WINDOW
ELENA TAPS AND MIMES "HELLO", GESTURING TOWARD A TABLE BEHIND FLOYD WHERE THEY ALL SIT DOWN FLOYD

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly, sir. Just let us have your name and Bank identification for V.P.I., and then give the name and address of the person you'd like the pet delivered to and it will be delivered tomorrow. SOME TIME DURING THIS CONVERSATION, FLOYD SEE ELENA, SMYSLOV AND THE OTHER TWO RUSSIANS PASS HIS VISION PHONE WINDOW. ELENA TAPS AND MIMES "HELLO", GESTURING TOWARD A TABLE BEHIND FLOYD WHERE THEY ALL SIT DOWN FLOYD Thank you very much. Floyd, Heywood, R.,  First National Bank of Washington. Please deliver to Miss Josephine Floyd, 9423 Dupre Avenue, N.W.14. 12/7/65                                                                                  b27 B19 CONTINUED VISION SALES GIRL Thank you very much, sir. It will be delivered tomorrow. 12/7/65                                                                                  b27a B20 SPACE STATTION 5 - LOUNGE FLOYD Well, how nice to see you again, Elena. You're looking wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: AND THE TWO OTHER RUSSIAN WOMEN STAND UP AND SMILE THEY SHAKE HANDS AFTER INTRODUCTION AND AD-LIB 'HELLOS' ELENA
RUSSIANS ARE VERY WARM AND FRIENDLY

dialogue.raw_text: How nice to see you, Hyewood. This is my good friend, Dr. Heywood Floyd. I'd like you to meet Andre Smyslov... SMYSLOV AND THE TWO OTHER RUSSIAN WOMEN STAND UP AND SMILE THEY SHAKE HANDS AFTER INTRODUCTION AND AD-LIB 'HELLOS' ELENA And this is Dr. Kalinan... Stretyneva... THE RUSSIANS ARE VERY WARM AND FRIENDLY.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: IS A BIT OF CONFUSION AS ALL REALISE THERE IS NOT ENOUGH ROOM FOR ANOTHER PERSON AT THE TABLE
OFFERS FLOYD HIS CHAIR AND BORROWS ANOTHER FROM A NEARBY TABLE SYMYSLOV

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Floyd, won't you join us for a drink? 12/7/65                                                                                  b28 B20 CONTINUED FLOYD I'm afraid I've only got a few minutes, but I'd love to. THERE IS A BIT OF CONFUSION AS ALL REALISE THERE IS NOT ENOUGH ROOM FOR ANOTHER PERSON AT THE TABLE. SMYSLOV OFFERS FLOYD HIS CHAIR AND BORROWS ANOTHER FROM A NEARBY TABLE SYMYSLOV What would you like to drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I really don't have time for a drink. If it's all right I'll just sit for a minute and then I've got to be off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you quite sure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, really, thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... How's your lovely wife? 12/7/65                                                                                  b29 B20 CONTINUED FLOYD She's wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And your charming little daughter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, she's growing up very fast. As a matter of fact, she's six tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's such a delightful age.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is gregor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's fine. But I'm afraid we don't get a chance to see each other very much these days. POLITE LAUGHTER FLOYD Well, where are all of you off to? 12/7/65                                                                                  b30 B20 CONTINUED ELENA Actually, we're on our way back from the moon. We've just spent three months calibrating the new antenna at Tchalinko. And what about you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, as it happens, I'm on my way up to the moon
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you, by any chance, going up to your base at Clavius?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes,as a matter of fact, I am. THE RUSSIANS EXCHANGE SIGNIFICANT GLANCES FLOYD Is there any particular reason why you ask? 12/7/65                                                                                  b31 B20 CONTINUED SMYSLOV (pleasantly)  Well, Dr. Floyd, I hope that you don't think I'm too inquisitive, but perhaps you can clear up the mystery about what's been going on up there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, but I'm not sure I know what you mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's just for the past two weeks there have been some extremely odd things happening at Clavius.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Well, for one thing, whenever you phone the base, all you can get is a recording which repeats that the phone lines are temporarily out of order. 12/7/65                                                                                  b32 B20 CONTINUED FLOYD Well, I suppose they've been having a bit of trouble with some of the equipment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, well at first we thought that was the explanation, but it's been going on for the past ten days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you haven't been able to get anyone at the base for ten days?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another thing, Heywood, two days ago, one of our rocket buses was denied permission for an emergency landing at Clavius. 12/7/65                                                                                  b33 B20 CONTINUED FLOYD How did they manage to do that without any communication?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clavius Control came on the air just long enough to transmit their refusal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that does sound very odd.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, and I'm afaid there's going to be a bit of a row about it. Denying the men permission to land was a direct violation of the I.A.S. convention.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... Well, I hope the crew got back safely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fortunately, they did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: B20 CONTINUED THE RUSSIANS EXCHANGE MORE GLANCES
ONE OF THE WOMEN OFFERS AROUND A PILL BOX
AND ANOTHER RUSSIAN TAKE ONE AND THE THIRD RUSSIAN DELCINES

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm glad about that. 12/7/65                                                                                  b33a B20 CONTINUED THE RUSSIANS EXCHANGE MORE GLANCES. ONE OF THE WOMEN OFFERS AROUND A PILL BOX. ELENA AND ANOTHER RUSSIAN TAKE ONE AND THE THIRD RUSSIAN DELCINES.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Floyd, at the risk of pressing you on a point you seem reticent to discuss, may I ask you a straightforward question?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite frankly, we have had some very reliable intelligence reports that a quite serious epidemic has broken out at Clavius. Something, apperently, of an unknown origin. Is this, in fact, what has happened? A LONG, AWKWARD PAUSE 12/7/65                                                                                  b33b B20 CONTINUED FLOYD I'm sorry, Dr. Smyslov, but I'm really not at liberty to discuss this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This epidemic could easily spread to our base, Dr. Floyd. We should be given all the facts. LONG PAUSE FLOYD Dr. Smyslov... I'm not permitted to discuss this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure you won't change your mind about a drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, thank you... and I'm afraid now I really must be going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I hope that you and your wife can come to the I.A.C. conference in June. 12/7/65                                                                                  b33c B20 CONTINUED FLOYD We're trying to get there. I hope we can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Gregor and I will look forward to seeing you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: RUSSIANS ALL RISE AND THERE ARE AD-LIBS OF COURTESY FLOYD SHAKES HANDS AND EXITS THE RUSSIANS EXCHANGE A FEW SERIOUS PARA- GRAPHES IN RUSSIAN 12/7/65

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. It's been a great pleasure to meet all of you... Dr. Smyslov. THE RUSSIANS ALL RISE AND THERE ARE AD-LIBS OF COURTESY FLOYD SHAKES HANDS AND EXITS THE RUSSIANS EXCHANGE A FEW SERIOUS PARA- GRAPHES IN RUSSIAN 12/7/65                                                                                  b33d
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: MUCH SMALLER THAN AS SEEN FROM SPACE STATION NARRATOR

IS ASLEEP, STRETCHED OUT IN THE CHAIR, COVERED WITH BLANKETS WHICH ARE HELD SECURE BY STRAPS A STEWARDESS SITS AT THE OTHER SIDE OF THE CABIN, WATCHING A KARATE EXHIBITION BETWEEN TWO WOMEN ON TELEVISION THE ELEVATOR ENTRANCE DOOR OPENS AND THE SECOND STEWARDESS ENTERS CARRYING A TRAY OF FOOD SHE BRINGS IT TO THE OTHER STEWARDESS STEWARDESS ONE

direction.raw_text: . EARTH MUCH SMALLER THAN AS SEEN FROM SPACE STATION NARRATOR The Aries-IB has become the standard Space-Station-to-Lunar surface vehicle. It was powered by low-thrust plasma jets which would continue the mild acceler- ation for fifteen minutes. Then the ship would break the bonds of gravity and be a free and indepen- dent planet, circling the Sun in an orbit of its own. 10/4/65                                                                                  b34 B21a ARIES PASSENGER AREA. FLOYD IS ASLEEP, STRETCHED OUT IN THE CHAIR, COVERED WITH BLANKETS WHICH ARE HELD SECURE BY STRAPS A STEWARDESS SITS AT THE OTHER SIDE OF THE CABIN, WATCHING A KARATE EXHIBITION BETWEEN TWO WOMEN ON TELEVISION THE ELEVATOR ENTRANCE DOOR OPENS AND THE SECOND STEWARDESS ENTERS CARRYING A TRAY OF FOOD SHE BRINGS IT TO THE OTHER STEWARDESS STEWARDESS ONE Oh, thank you very much.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I see he's still asleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: EXITS FROM ELEVATOR, GOES TO KITCHEN SECTION, REMOVES TWO TRAYS, WALKS UP TO THE SIDE OF THE WALL AND ENTERS PILOT'S COMPARTMENT 12/6/65

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. He hasn't moved since we left. STEWARDESS TWO EXITS, INTO ELEVATOR 12/6/65                                                                                  b34a B21b ARIES GALLEY AREA. STEWARDESS EXITS FROM ELEVATOR, GOES TO KITCHEN SECTION, REMOVES TWO TRAYS, WALKS UP TO THE SIDE OF THE WALL AND ENTERS PILOT'S COMPARTMENT 12/6/65                                                                                  b34b B22 ARIES-IB COCKPIT. PILOT, CO-PILOT. STEWARDESS ENTERS, CARRYING FOOD PILOT Oh, thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. STEWARDESS SMILES.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs)  Well, how's it going back there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. Very quiet. He's been asleep since we left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, no one can say that he's not enjoying the wonders of Space.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, whatever's going on up there, he's going to arrive fresh and ready to go. 12/14/65                                                                                 b35 B22 CONTINUED PILOT I wonder what really IS going on up there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I've heard more and more people talk of an epidemic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose it was bound to happen sooner or later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Berkeley told me that they think it came from contamination on a returning Mars flight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, well, whatever it is, they're certainly not fooling around. This is the first flight they allowed in for more than a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was working out what this trip must cost, taking him up there by himself and coming back empty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll bet it's a fortune. 12/14/65                                                                                 b36
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Well, at ten thousand dollars a ticket, it comes to the better part of six hundred thousand dollars.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, as soon as he wakes up, I'm going to go back and talk to him. I must say, I'd like to find out what's going on. 12/14/65                                                                                 b36a B23 ARIES-IB IN SPACE. MOON VERY LARGE. 10/4/65                                                                                  b37 B24 ARIES-IB PASSENGER AREA. FLOYD FINISHING BREAKFAST. PILOT ENTERS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, good afternoon, Dr. Floyd. Did you have a good rest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, marvellous. It's the first real sleep I've had for the past two days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing like weightless sleep for a complete rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When do we arrive at Clavius?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're scheduled to dock in about seven hours. Is there anything we can do for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, thank you. The two girls have taken wonderful care of me. I'm just fine. 12/14/65                                                                                 b38 B24 CONTINUED PILOT Well, if there is anything that you wnat, just give a holler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Incidentally, Dr. Floyd, I wonder if I can have a word with you about the security arrangements?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... the crew is confined to the ship when we land at Clavius. We have to stay inside for the time it take to refit - about twenty-four hours. And then we're going to back empty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I take it this is something to do with the trouble they're having up at Clavius? 12/14/65                                                                                 b39 B24 CONTINUED FLOYD I'm afraid that's out of my depart- ment, Captain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'll tell you why I ask. You see, I've got a girl who works in the Auditing Department of the Territorial Administrator and I haven't been able to get her on the phone for the past week or so, and with all these stories one hears, I'm a little concerned about her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. Well, I'm sorry about that. I wouldn't think there's any cause for alarm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, well, I wouldn't have been too concerned about it, except I've heard these stories about the epidemic and, as a matter of fact, I've heard that ten people have died already. 12/14/65                                                                                 b40 B24 CONTINUED FLOYD I wish I could be more helpful, Captain, but as I've said, I don't think there's any cause for alarm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, fine. Thanks very much, anyway, and I hope you don't mind me asking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, of course, Captain, I can understand your concern.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, thank you very much, and please let us know if there is anything we can do to make your trip more comfortable. 12/14/65                                                                                 b40a B25 ARIES-IB CLOSER TO MOON 10/4/65                                                                                  b41
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: b42 B27 ARIES-IB CLOSER TO MOON DISSOLVE: 10/4/65                                                                                  b43 B28 FLOYD VISITING ARIES-IB COCKPIT. WEIGHTLESS TRICK ENTRANCE. 10/4/65                                                                                  b44
direction.name: direction

result.heading: B26 FLOYD GOES TO ARIES-IB WASHROOM AND LOOKS AT THE VERY LONG LIST OF COMPLICATED INSTRUCTIONS 10/4/65
THE CREW AND DOCKING CONTROL PEOPLE ON THE MOON GO THROUGH THEIR DOCKING ROUTINE
THIS HAS THE RITUALISTIC TONE AND CADENCE OF PRESENT- DAY JET LANDING PROCEDURE

dialogue.raw_text: The laws of Earthly aesthetics did not apply here, this world had been shaped and molded by other than terrestrial forces, operating over aeons of time unknown to the young, verdant Earth, with its fleeting Ice-Ages, its swiftly rising and falling seas, its mountain ranges dissolving like mists before the dawn. Here was age inconceivable - but not death, for the Moon had never lived until now. 10/4/65                                                                                  b45 B30 ARIES-IB COCKPIT - THE CREW AND DOCKING CONTROL PEOPLE ON THE MOON GO THROUGH THEIR DOCKING ROUTINE. THIS HAS THE RITUALISTIC TONE AND CADENCE OF PRESENT- DAY JET LANDING PROCEDURE. WE ONLY HEAR DOCKING CONTROL. 10/4/65                                                                                  b46 B31 ARIES-IB DECENDING. SEE AIR VIEW OF BASE.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Base at Clavius was the first American Lunar Settlement that could, in an emergency, be entirely self-supporting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: B32 A GROUND BUS NUZZLES UP TO COUPLING SECTION OF ARIES-IB 10/4/65

dialogue.raw_text: Water and all the necessities of life for its eleven hundred men, women and children were produced from the Lunar rocks, after they had been crushed, heated and chemically processed. 10/4/65                                                                                  b47 B32 A GROUND BUS NUZZLES UP TO COUPLING SECTION OF ARIES-IB 10/4/65                                                                                  b48
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GROUND BUS PULLS IN. GIANT DOORS CLOSE BEHIND IT. 10/4/65                                                                                  b49
direction.name: direction

SEE PEOPLE WAITING IN GLASSED-IN SECTION WAITING FOR SECOND AIRLOCK DOORS TO CLOSE. 10/4/65                                                                                  b50 B35 LOW GRAVITY GYMNASIUM TRICK WITH CHILDREN.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: SHOWING THEM VIEWS OF EARTH AND MAP OF EARTH

dialogue.raw_text: One of the attractions of life on the Moon was undoubtedly the low gravity which produced a sense of general well-being. 10/4/65                                                                                  b51 B36 CHILDREN IN SCHOOL. TEACHER SHOWING THEM VIEWS OF EARTH AND MAP OF EARTH.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: DOORS BRANCHING OFF TO DIFF- RENT MAIN HALLS
SMALL POND WITH PLASTIC WHITE SWAN AND A BIT OF GRASS
FEW BENCHES WITH THREE WOMEN AND THEIR CHILDREN HAVING OUTING
AND WELCOMING PARTY WALK THROUGH AFTER EXITING ELEVATOR

dialogue.raw_text: The personnel of the Base and their children were the forerunners of new nations, new cultures that would ultimately spread out across the solar system. They no longer thought of Earth as home. The time was fast approaching when Earth, like all mothers, must say farewell to her children. DISSOLVE: 10/5/65                                                                                  b52 B37 LARGE CENTRAL RECEPTION AREA. DOORS BRANCHING OFF TO DIFF- RENT MAIN HALLS. SMALL POND WITH PLASTIC WHITE SWAN AND A BIT OF GRASS. A FEW BENCHES WITH THREE WOMEN AND THEIR CHILDREN HAVING OUTING. FLOYD AND WELCOMING PARTY WALK THROUGH AFTER EXITING ELEVATOR. HALVERSON, MICHAELS AND FIVE OTHERS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (voice echoing)  I must congratulate you Halvorsen. you've done wonder- ful things with the decor since the last time I was here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: B38 LOW CEILING CONFERENCE ROOM, "U" SHAPED TABLE FACING THREE PROJECTION SCREENS
SEATED AROUND THE TABLE ARE TWENTY SENIOR BASE PERSONNEL

dialogue.raw_text: (voice echoing)  Well... thank you, Dr. Floyd. We try to make the environment as earthlike as possible. DISSOLVE: 10/5/65                                                                                  b53 B38 LOW CEILING CONFERENCE ROOM, "U" SHAPED TABLE FACING THREE PROJECTION SCREENS. SEATED AROUND THE TABLE ARE TWENTY SENIOR BASE PERSONNEL.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: FLOYD WALKS TO FRONT OF ROOM

dialogue.raw_text: Ladies and gentlemen, I should like to introduce Dr. Heywood Floyd, a distinguished member of the National Council of Astronautics. He has just completed a special flight here from Earth to be with us, and before the briefing he would like to say a few words. Dr. Floyd. POLITE APPLAUSE. FLOYD WALKS TO FRONT OF ROOM.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First of all, I bring a personal message from Dr. Howell, who has asked me to convey his deepest appreciation to all of you for the personal sacrifices you have made, and of course his congratulations on your discovery which may well prove to be among the most significant in the history of science. POLITE APPLAUSE. 11/25/65                                                                                 b54 B38 CONTINUED FLOYD (cont'd) Mr. Halvorsen has made known to me some of the conflicting views held by many of you regarding the need for complete security in this matter, and more specifically your strong opposition to the cover story created to give the impression there is an epidemic at the Base. I understand that beyond it being a matter of principle, many of you are troubled by the concern and anxiety this story of an epidemic might cause your relatives and friends on Earth. I can understand and sympathize with your negative views. I have been personally embarrassed by this cover story. But I fully accept the need for absolute secrecy and I hope you will. It should not be difficult for all of you to realise the potential for cutural shock and social disorientation contained in the present situation if the facts were prematurely and suddenly made public without adequate preparation and conditioning. 11/25/65                                                                                 b55 B38 CONTINUED FLOYD This is the view of the Council and the purpose of my visit here is to gather addition facts and opinions on the situation and to prepare a report to the Council recommending when and how the news should eventually be announced. Are there any questions?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Floyd, how long do you think this can be kept under wraps?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: B39 SEVERAL SCENIC VIEWS OF MOON ROCKET BUS SKIMMING OVER SURFACE OF MOON
B40 INSIDE ROCKET BUS, FLOYD, HALVORSEN, MICHAELS, FOURTH MAN, PILOT AND CO-PILOT
ALL IN SPACE SUITS MINUS HELMETS
IS SLOWELY LOOKING THROUGH SOME PHOTOGRAPHS AND MAGNETIC MAPS OF THE AREA
LOOKS OUT OF THE WINDOW, THOUGHTFULLY
B40 CONTINUED THE PHOTOGRAPHES ARE TAKEN FROM A SATELLITE OF THE MOON'S SURFACE AND HAVE NUMBERED OPTICAL GRID BORDERS, LIKE RECENT MARS PHOTOS
FEW SEATS AWAY, MICHAELS AND HALVORSEN CARRY OUT A VERY BANAL ADMINISTRATIVE CONVERSATION IN LOW TONES
IT SHOULD REVOLVE AROUND SOMETHING UTTERLY IRRELEVANT TO THE PRESENT CIRCUMSTANCES AND VERY MUCH LIKE THE KIND OF DISCUSSION ONE HEARS ALL THE TIME IN OTHER ORGANIZATIONS
ARE NO LIGHTS ON THE ACTUAL EXCA- VATION, ONLY THE LANDING STRIP AND THE MONITOR DOME
SHOT MONITOR DOMES WITH A BIT OF EXCAVATION IN SHOT
SIX SMALL FIGURES IN SPACE SUITS SLOWLY WALK TOWARD EXCAVATION

dialogue.raw_text: (pleasantly) I'm afraid it can and it will be kept under wraps as long as it is deemed to be necessary by the Council. And of course you know that the Council has requested that formal security oaths are to be obtained in writing from every- one who had any knowledge of this event. There must be adequate time for a full study to be made of the situation before any con- sideration can be given to making a public announcement. 11/25/65                                                                                 b56 B38 CONTINUED HALVORSEN We will, of course, cooperate in any way possible, Dr. Floyd. 11/25/65                                                                                 b56a B39 SEVERAL SCENIC VIEWS OF MOON ROCKET BUS SKIMMING OVER SURFACE OF MOON. 10/5/65                                                                                  b57 B40 INSIDE ROCKET BUS, FLOYD, HALVORSEN, MICHAELS, FOURTH MAN, PILOT AND CO-PILOT. ALL IN SPACE SUITS MINUS HELMETS. FLOYD IS SLOWELY LOOKING THROUGH SOME PHOTOGRAPHS AND MAGNETIC MAPS OF THE AREA. HE LOOKS OUT OF THE WINDOW, THOUGHTFULLY. 11/25/65                                                                                 b58 B40 CONTINUED THE PHOTOGRAPHES ARE TAKEN FROM A SATELLITE OF THE MOON'S SURFACE AND HAVE NUMBERED OPTICAL GRID BORDERS, LIKE RECENT MARS PHOTOS. A FEW SEATS AWAY, MICHAELS AND HALVORSEN CARRY OUT A VERY BANAL ADMINISTRATIVE CONVERSATION IN LOW TONES. IT SHOULD REVOLVE AROUND SOMETHING UTTERLY IRRELEVANT TO THE PRESENT CIRCUMSTANCES AND VERY MUCH LIKE THE KIND OF DISCUSSION ONE HEARS ALL THE TIME IN OTHER ORGANIZATIONS. DISSOLVE: 11/25/65                                                                                 b59 B41 TMA-1 EXCAVATION. AIR VIEW. ROCKET BUS DESCENDING. THERE ARE NO LIGHTS ON THE ACTUAL EXCA- VATION, ONLY THE LANDING STRIP AND THE MONITOR DOME. 12/14/65                                                                                 b60 B42 LONG SHOT MONITOR DOMES WITH A BIT OF EXCAVATION IN SHOT. SIX SMALL FIGURES IN SPACE SUITS SLOWLY WALK TOWARD EXCAVATION. 10/5/65                                                                                  b61
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: MOUNTED AT THE HEAD OF THE RAMP
MICHAELS THROWS A SWITCH AND THE EXCAVATION IS SUDDENLY ILLUMINATED

direction.raw_text: . A SMALL CONTROL PANEL MOUNTED AT THE HEAD OF THE RAMP. MICHAELS THROWS A SWITCH AND THE EXCAVATION IS SUDDENLY ILLUMINATED.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: B43 THE PARTY STOPS AT TOP OF TMA-1 EXCAVATION

dialogue.raw_text: Well, there it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can we go down there closer to it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly. 12/14/65                                                                                 b62
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Does your geology on it still check out?
direction.name: direction

result.heading: B44 THEY START DOWN WORKING RAMP FLOYD

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, it does. The sub-surface structure shows that it was deliberately buried about four million years ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can you tell it was deliberately buried?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By the deformation between the mother rock and the fill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any clue as to what it is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not really. It's completely inert. No sound or energy sources have been detected. The surface is made of something incredibly hard and we've been barely able to scratch it. A laser drill 11/25/65                                                                                 b63 B44 CONTINUED MICHAELS might do something, but we don't want to be too rough until we know a little more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you don't have any idea as to what it is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomb, shine, survey-marker spare part, take your choice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The only thing about it that we are sure of is that it is the first direct evidence of intelligent life beyond the Earth. SILENT APPRECIATION HALVORSEN Four million years ago, something, presumably from the stars, must have swept through the solar system and left this behind. 11/25/65                                                                                 b64 B44 CONTINUED FLOYD Was it abandoned, forgotten, left for a purpose?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose we'll never know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The moon would have made an excellent base camp for preliminary Earth surveys. SOME MORE SILENCE FLOYD Any ideas about the colour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, not really. At first glance, black would suggest something sun-powered, but then why would anyone deliberately bury a sun- powered device?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Has it been exposed to any sun before now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: B45 INSIDE MONITOR DOME WE SEE A NUMBER OF TELEVISION DISPLAYS INCLUDING SEVERAL TV VIEWS OF FLOYD AND COMPANY IN THE EXCAVATION

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think it has, but I'd like to check that. Simpson, what's the log on that? 11/25/65                                                                                 b65 B45 INSIDE MONITOR DOME WE SEE A NUMBER OF TELEVISION DISPLAYS INCLUDING SEVERAL TV VIEWS OF FLOYD AND COMPANY IN THE EXCAVATION.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The first surface was exposed at
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: on the 12th April... Let me see... that would have been forty-five minutes after Lunar sun-set. I see here that special lighting equipment had to be brought up before any futher work could be done. 11/25/65                                                                                 b66 B46 TMA-1 EXCAVATION MICHAELS Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And so this is the first sun that it's had in four million years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: PHOTOGRAPHER QUICKLY MAKES SOME EXPOSURES PHOTOGRAPHER
THE MEN SLOWLY SEPERATE FROM THEIR PICTURE POSE, THERE IS A PIERCINGLY POWERFUL SERIES OF FIVE ELECTRONIC SHRIEKS, EACH LIKE A HIDEOUSLY OVER-LOADED AND DISTORTED TIME SIGNAL
INVOLUNTARILY TRIES TO BLOCK HIS EARS WITH HIS SPACESUITED HANDS

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, gentlemen, if you'd all line up on this side of the walkway we'd like to take a few photographes. Dr. Floyd, would you thand in the middle... Dr. Michaels on that side, Mr. Halvorsen on the other.... thank you. THE PHOTOGRAPHER QUICKLY MAKES SOME EXPOSURES PHOTOGRAPHER Thank you very much gentlemen, I'll have the base photo section send you copies. AS THE MEN SLOWLY SEPERATE FROM THEIR PICTURE POSE, THERE IS A PIERCINGLY POWERFUL SERIES OF FIVE ELECTRONIC SHRIEKS, EACH LIKE A HIDEOUSLY OVER-LOADED AND DISTORTED TIME SIGNAL. FLOYD INVOLUNTARILY TRIES TO BLOCK HIS EARS WITH HIS SPACESUITED HANDS. THEN COMES MERCIFUL SILENCE. 11/25/65                                                                                 b67 B47 VARIOUS SHOTS OF SPACE MONITORS, ASTEROIDS, THE SUN, PLUTO, MARS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A hundred million miles beyond Mars, in the cold lonliness where no man had yet travelled, Deep-Space-Monitor-79 drifts slowly among the tangled orbits of the asteroids.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Radiation detectors noted and analyzed incoming cosmic rays from the galaxy and points beyond; neutron and x-ray telescopes kept watch on strange stars that no human eye would eever see; magnetometers observed the gusts and hurricanes of the solar winds, as the sun breathed million mile-an-hour blasts of plasma into the faces of its circling children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All these things and many others were patiently noted by Deep- Space-Monitor-79, and recorded in its crystalline memory. 11/25/65                                                                                 b68 B47 CONTINUED NARRATOR But now it had noted something strange - the faint yet unmistakable distrubance rippling across the solar system, and quite unlike any natural phenomena it had ever observed in the past.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was also observed by Orbiter
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: circling Mars twice a day; and High Inclination Probe-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: climbing slowly above the planet of the ecliptic; and even artificial Comet-5, heading out into the cold wastes beyond Pluto, along an orbit whose far point it would not reach for a thousand years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All noticed the peculiar burst of energy that leaped from the face of the Moon and moved across the solar system, throwing off a spray of radiation like the wake of a racing speedboat. 11/25/65                                                                                 b69 B SECTION TIMING B1-1f
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .30 B SECTION TOTAL:  28 MIN. 10 SECS. TITLE
direction.name: direction

PRESSES NECESSARY BUTTONS TO OPERATE AIRLOCK DOOR TO POD BAY

dialogue.raw_text: b69a C1 DISCOVERY 1,000,000 MILES FROM EARTH. SEE EARTH AND MOON SMALL. WE SEE A BLINDING FLASH EVERY 5 SECONDS FROM ITS NUCLEAR PULSE PROPULSION. IT STRIKES AGAINST THE SHIP'S THICK ABLATIVE TAIL PLATE. SEVERAL CUTS OF THIS. 11/19/65                                                                                 c1 C2 ANOTHER CLOSER VIEW OF DISCOVERY. SEE BOWMAN THROUGH COMMAND MODULE WINDOW. 11/19/65                                                                                 c2 C3 BOWMAN INSIDE DISCOVERY COMMAND MODULE. HE IS LOOKING FOR SOMETHING. COMPUTER READOUT DISPLAY SHOWING AN EVER-SHIFTING ASSORTMENT OF COLOR-CODED LINEAR PROJECTIONS. WE SEE POOLE IN BACKGROUND IN COMPUTER BRAIN CENTRE AREA. AFTER A FEW SECONDS HE EXITS. SUDDENLY HE FINDS IT - HIS ELECTRONIC NEWSPAD. HE EXITS POD BAY. 11/19/65                                                                                 c5 C6 IN THE AIRLOCK- LINK BOWMAN OPERATES BUTTONS TO OPEN DOOR MARKED "CENTRIFUGE". 11/19/65                                                                                 c6
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi. Frank... coming in, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Just a sec.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. (pause)
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.ToD: SEE THE ROTATING HUB COLLAR AT THE END

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, come on down. WE SEE THE ROTATING HUB COLLAR AT THE END. BEHIND IT WE SEE 11/19/65                                                                                 c7 C8 THE CENTRIFUGE TV-DISPLAY SHOWING SLEEPERS AND POOLE SLOWLY ROTATING BY. POOLE SECURES SOME LOOSE GEAR. POOLE LOOKS UP TO TV MONITOR LENS AND WAVES. 11/19/65                                                                                 c8 C9 BOWMAN AT PANEL. STOPS ROTATION AND MOVES TO ENTRY PORT. WHEN ROTATION STOPS WE SEE A SIGN LIGHTS UP "WEIGHTLESS CONDITION". AS BOWMAN DISAPPEARS DOWN ENTRY PORT WE SEE HIM ON TV-MONITOR, DESCENDING LADDER. AT THE BASE OF THE LADDER HE KEYS THE CENTRIFUGE OPERATION PANEL. WE SEE TV-PICTURE START TO ROTATE AGAIN. "WEIGHTLESS CONDITION" SIGN GOES OUT. 11/19/65                                                                                 c9 C10 INSIDE CENTRIFUGE BOWMAN MAKES 180 DEGREE WALK TO POOLE. ON WAY HE PASSES THE SLEEPERS. WE GET A GOOD LOOK AT THE THREE MEN IN THEIR HIBERNACULUMS. POOLE IS SEATED AT A TABLE READING HIS ELECTRONIC NEWSPAD.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Hi... How's it going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

C11 DISCOVERY IN SPACE, STILL NUCLEAR PULSING

dialogue.raw_text: (absent but friendly)  Great. BOWMAN OPERATES ARTIFICIAL FOOD UNIT, TAKES HIS TRAY AND SITS DOWN. KEYS ON HIS ELECTRONIC NEWSPAD AND BEGINS TO EAT. BOTH MEN EAT IN A FRIENDLY AND RELAXED SILENCE. 11/19/65                                                                                 c10 C11 DISCOVERY IN SPACE, STILL NUCLEAR PULSING. EARTH AND MOON CAN BE SEEN IN BACKGROUND. DISSOLVE: 11/19/65                                                                                 c11 C12 POOLE IS FINISHED. BOWMAN IS STILL READING AND WORKING ON HIS DESSERT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dave, if you've a minute, I'd like your advice on something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's nothing really important, but it's annoying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's about my salary cheques.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well I got the papers on my official up-grading to AGS-19 two weeks before we left. 12/14/65                                                                                 c12 C12 CONTINUED BOWMAN Yes, I remember you mentioning it. I got mine about the same time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. Well, naturally, I didn't say anything to Payroll. I assumed they'd start paying me at the higher grade on the next pay cheque. But it's been almost three weeks now and I'm still being paid as an AGS-18.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Interesting that you mention it, because I've got the same problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yesterday, I finally called the Accounting Office at Mission Control, and all they could tell me was that they'd received the AGS-19 notification for the other three but not mine, and apparently not yours either. 12/14/65                                                                                 c13 C12 CONTINUED BOWMAN Did they have any explanation for this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not really. They just said it might be because we trained at Houston and they trained in Marshall, and that we're being charged against differ- ent accounting offices.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what do you think we ought to do about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think we should make any fuss about it yet. I'm sure they'll straighten it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must say, I never did understand why they split us into two groups for training.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I never did, either. 12/14/65                                                                                 c14 C12 CONTINUED POOLE We spent so little time with them, I have trouble keeping their names straight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose the idea was specialized training.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose so. Though, of course, there's a more sinister explanation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. You must have heard the rumour that went around during orbital check-out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, as a matter of fact, I didn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, well, apparently there's something about the mission that the sleeping beauties know that we don't know, and that's why we were trained separately and that's why they were put to sleep before they were even taken aboard. 12/14/65                                                                                 c15 C12 CONTINUED BOWMAN Well, what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. All I heard is that there's something about the mission we weren't told.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That seems very unlikely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I thought so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, it would be very easy for us to find out now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just ask Hal. It's conceivable they might keep something from us, but they'd never keep anything from Hal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: WALKS TO THE HAL 9000 COMPUTER POOLE

dialogue.raw_text: That's true. 12/14/65                                                                                 c15a C12 CONINUED BOWMAN (sighs)  Well... it's silly, but... if you want to, why don't you? POOLE WALKS TO THE HAL 9000 COMPUTER POOLE Hal... Dave and I believe that there's something about the mission that we weren't told. Something that the rest of the crew know and that you know. We'd like to know whether this is true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, Frank, but I don't think I can answer that question without knowing everything that all of you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's got a point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, then how do we re-phrase the question? 12/14/65                                                                                 c15c
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Still, you really don't believe it, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 0800                                 WAKES UP a2                                                                  b2 BEDTIME SNACK                         0900                                 BREAKFAST a3                                                                  b3 TO SLEEP WITH                         1000                                 GYMNASIUM INSTANT ELECTRO- NARCOSIS AND EAR PLUGS. a4                                                                  b4 SLEEP
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 2200                                 FAMILY AND SOCIAL TV CHAT                                                          TV CHAT a16                                                                 b16 FILMS
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Not really. Though, it is strange when you think about it. It didn't really make any sense to keep us apart during training.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but it's to fantastic to think that they'd keep something from us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. It would be almost inconceivable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But not completely inconceivable?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose it isn't logically impossible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess it isn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still, all we have to do is ask Hal. 12/14/65                                                                                 c15b C12 CONTINUED
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the only important aspect of the mission are: where are we going, what will we do when we get there, when are we coming back, and... why are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Hal, tell me whether the following statements are true or false.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will if I can, Frank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our Mission Profile calls for Discovery going to Saturn. True or false?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: True.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our transit time is 257 days. Is that true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's true. 12/14/65                                                                                 c15d C12 CONTINUED
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the end of a hundred days of exploration, we will all go into hibernation. Is this true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Approximately five years after we go into hibernation, the recovery vehicle will make rendezous with us and bring us back. Is this true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's true
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no other purpose for this mission than to carry out a continuation of the space program, and to further our general knowledge of the planets. Is that true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you very much, Hal. 12/14/65                                                                                 c15e C12 CONTINUED
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: PARENTS ARE SEEN ON THE VISION SCREEN

dialogue.raw_text: c46 C18 DISCOVERY IN SPACE 11/24/65                                                                                 c47 C19 CENTRIFUGE BOWMAN SITTING AT PERSONAL COMMUNI- CATION PANEL. POOLE STANDING NEARBY. BOWMAN'S PARENTS ARE SEEN ON THE VISION SCREEN. MOTHER, FATHER AND YOUNGER SISTER. THEY ARE ALL SINGING "HAPPY BIRTHDAY". THE PARENTS, POOLE AND HAL. THE SONG ENDS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, David there is a man telling us that we've used up our time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David... again we want to wish you a happy Birthday and God speed. We'll talk to you again tomorrow. 'Bye, 'bye now. CHORUS OF "GOODBYES". 12/13/65                                                                                 c48 C19 CONTINUED VISION SCREEN GOES BLANK HAL Sorry to interrupt the festivities, Dave, but I think we've got a problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it, Hal?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: DISPLAYS DIAGRAM OF SKELETONISED PICTURE OF SHIP

dialogue.raw_text: .P.C. shows an impending failure of the antenna orientation unit. C20 TV DISPLAYS DIAGRAM OF SKELETONISED PICTURE OF SHIP. 12/13/65
